title: What are healthy cooking oils?
content: Olive oil, avocado oil, and canola oil are considered heart-healthy. Coconut oil is good for high-heat cooking but should be used in moderation due to saturated fat.

title: How many calories are in a boiled egg?
content: A single boiled egg contains about 70–78 calories and is a good source of protein, vitamins, and healthy fats.

title: Vegan protein sources
content: Vegan diets can include protein from lentils, chickpeas, tofu, tempeh, seitan, quinoa, chia seeds, and almonds.

title: Quick Breakfast Ideas
content: Overnight oats, smoothies, Greek yogurt with fruits, boiled eggs with toast, and peanut butter banana wraps are all healthy and quick breakfast options.

title: Is brown rice healthier than white rice?
content: Yes, brown rice retains the bran and germ, making it richer in fiber, vitamins, and minerals than white rice.

title: What is the glycemic index of foods?
content: The glycemic index (GI) ranks carbohydrates based on how they affect blood sugar levels. Low-GI foods (like oats, lentils, and non-starchy vegetables) are better for blood sugar control.

title: Low-carb meal options
content: Zucchini noodles, cauliflower rice, grilled chicken salad, and egg muffins are great low-carb meals.

title: What is intermittent fasting?
content: Intermittent fasting is an eating pattern where you cycle between periods of eating and fasting, such as 16:8 (16 hours fasting, 8 hours eating).

title: What are good sources of protein?
content: Good sources of protein include lean meats, poultry, fish, eggs, dairy products, legumes like lentils and beans, tofu, tempeh, nuts, and seeds.

title: How much protein do I need daily?
content: The average adult needs about 0.8 grams of protein per kilogram of body weight per day. Active individuals or athletes may need up to 1.2–2.0 grams per kilogram.

title: What are vegetarian sources of protein?
content: Vegetarian protein sources include paneer, lentils, chickpeas, quinoa, Greek yogurt, milk, soy milk, tofu, almonds, peanuts, chia seeds, and oats.

title: Is it safe to consume protein powder?
content: Protein powders are generally safe in moderate amounts, especially for athletes or those who have higher protein needs. Always choose high-quality products and consult a nutritionist if unsure.

title: What is complete protein?
content: A complete protein contains all nine essential amino acids. Examples include eggs, meat, fish, dairy, quinoa, soy products like tofu, and buckwheat.

title: Can I get enough protein from a vegan diet?
content: Yes, a well-planned vegan diet can meet all protein needs using foods like lentils, chickpeas, tofu, tempeh, soy milk, quinoa, nuts, seeds, and protein-rich vegetables.

title: High-protein breakfast ideas
content: Try Greek yogurt with nuts, eggs on whole-grain toast, peanut butter banana wrap, protein smoothie, or a chickpea salad sandwich.

title: How does protein help the body?
content: Protein supports muscle repair, immune function, hormone production, skin health, and enzyme activity. It's a key macronutrient for overall body function.

title: Can too much protein be harmful?
content: Excessive protein intake over time may strain the kidneys, especially in those with pre-existing conditions. It can also lead to dehydration and digestive issues if not balanced with fiber and fluids.

title: Protein content of common foods
content: 1 egg = 6g, 100g chicken breast = 31g, 1 cup cooked lentils = 18g, 100g paneer = 18g, 1 scoop whey protein = ~20–25g, 1 cup milk = 8g.

title: Does protein help with weight loss?
content: Yes, protein can aid in weight loss by increasing satiety, reducing cravings, and preserving muscle mass during calorie deficits. It also boosts metabolism slightly through the thermic effect of food.

title: When should I consume protein for muscle gain?
content: For muscle gain, consume protein throughout the day and especially after workouts. Aim for 20–30g of high-quality protein within 30–60 minutes post-exercise.

title: What are slow-digesting vs fast-digesting proteins?
content: Fast-digesting proteins like whey are ideal post-workout for quick absorption. Slow-digesting proteins like casein are better before bed as they release amino acids gradually over time.

title: How does protein affect blood sugar?
content: Protein has a minimal effect on blood sugar levels and may even help stabilize them when consumed with carbs, making it beneficial for people with diabetes.

title: What are signs of protein deficiency?
content: Signs include muscle loss, fatigue, hair thinning, brittle nails, weakened immunity, and slow wound healing. Severe deficiency can lead to kwashiorkor, especially in children.

title: Best protein-rich Indian vegetarian meals
content: Rajma-chawal, chole-chawal, dal with quinoa, palak paneer, moong dal chilla, besan cheela, soya chunks curry, and sprout salad are all rich in protein.

title: Protein myths debunked
content: Myth: Eating too much protein damages kidneys in healthy individuals. Fact: This is mostly untrue unless there's a pre-existing condition. Also, plant protein can be complete when combined properly.

title: High-Protein Chickpea Salad
content: This salad includes boiled chickpeas, cucumber, tomato, onion, lemon juice, and black salt. It's rich in plant protein, fiber, and makes a great mid-day meal.

title: Soya Chunks Curry
content: Made using soya chunks, onion, tomato, and Indian spices. Soya is one of the richest plant-based protein sources, perfect for vegetarians aiming to build muscle.

title: Moong Dal Chilla
content: A savory pancake made from soaked moong dal, green chilies, ginger, and veggies. It’s high in protein and a great breakfast option.

title: Paneer Bhurji
content: Scrambled paneer cooked with onion, tomato, turmeric, and spices. Great for breakfast or lunch, especially if you're looking for dairy-based protein.

title: Quinoa & Rajma Bowl
content: A power bowl with boiled quinoa, kidney beans (rajma), bell peppers, and light seasoning. A complete protein combo ideal for lunch.

title: Sprouted Moong Salad
content: Sprouted moong with onion, tomato, lemon, and chat masala. Easy to digest and protein-rich.

title: Grilled Chicken with Quinoa & Veggies
content: Marinated chicken breasts grilled and served with boiled quinoa and steamed vegetables. Rich in lean protein, fiber, and ideal for bulk meal prep.

title: Tofu Stir Fry with Brown Rice
content: Tofu cubes sautéed with bell peppers, broccoli, soy sauce, and sesame oil. Served with brown rice. High in plant protein and perfect for 3–4 meals.

title: Chickpea & Spinach Curry
content: Protein-packed curry made from boiled chickpeas, tomatoes, onions, and spinach. Stores well for up to 3 days. Serve with rice or roti.

title: Soya Masala Wraps
content: Spiced soya granules with onion and tomato, rolled in whole wheat wraps. Can be refrigerated and reheated. High in protein and great for lunch boxes.

title: Grilled Paneer & Vegetable Skewers
content: Paneer cubes and bell peppers grilled on skewers with herbs and lemon juice. Keeps well in the fridge and provides a protein-dense snack or side.

title: Rajma Quinoa Meal Box
content: Cooked kidney beans (rajma) in tomato masala served with boiled quinoa. A complete protein option, suitable for weekly meal prepping.

title: Best protein bars for post-workout
content: Look for bars with 15–25g protein, low sugar, and minimal additives. Brands like MyProtein, Quest, or homemade bars with oats, nut butter, and whey work well.

title: What is the thermic effect of protein?
content: Protein has a high thermic effect (20–30%), meaning your body uses more energy to digest it compared to fats (0–3%) and carbs (5–10%).

title: What is casein protein?
content: Casein is a slow-digesting dairy protein often consumed before bed to prevent muscle breakdown overnight. Found in cottage cheese and milk.
